divs: sighting detailsliving in a small housing village called "alpine village," on goshen road, in jewett, ny, greene county; ski-resort area in catskill mountains \ catskill state park. location is relatively isolated, surrounded by hundreds of acres of mountain forest. age 14 or 15, i was taking the garbage out to the dumpster. it was a moderate snow storm during the winter. the lot is heavily lighted by flood lights near the dumpster and on most of the housing units. the dumpster is roughly 30-40 feet from my house. as i was returning from the dumpster, i noticed it suddenly stopped snowing. i can't recall exactly why i looked up, but as i did, i noticed a large air craft moving at a eerily slow speed and low altitude overhead. my immediate reaction was "ufo, run," but i couldn't move out of fear. although i couldn't see much of the craft itself through the snow, the "blackness" of the craft versus the "brown-ness" of the sky\snow\floodlights allowed me to see a triangular profile. additionally, as the craft moved from directly overhead and off into the distance, i was able to see a side profile which would lead me to describe the craft as a wedge shape. the craft itself had many small white lights on the bottom. the craft was large enough, low enough, and moving slow enough to stop snowfall for roughly 10-15 seconds. it made no noise at all. the light from the floodlights was able to penetrate high enough to touch the craft through the snow; so i imagine the craft was at most 50-75 feet in the air. i would estimate the craft was at least 50 feet in length, probably much larger (i'm no good at judging distance\size) any air craft in this area and altitude, especially during a snow storm, would have been in great danger. i immediately reported this to my parents who didn't believe me. attached is a map showing the location of the sighting, and the direction the craft was moving in and away from.
trends: There have been no other sightings in Jewett
This sighting has never been favorited.
Summary: Sighting of low-altitude, slow-moving air craft during evening snow storm.
